posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
I am looking for examples from other teams of how they use LED lights for feedback. This includes both LED light strips and LED matrix boards such as the CTRE CANdle .

If I find examples from behind the bumpers I will post it here.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: How about LEDs on the roboRIO digital outputs? When troubleshooting the I2C bus lockups we used the DigitialOutputs with LEDs inserted to indicate where in the code the program stopped (count in binary, of course).

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: I found this brief example from team 27 Team Rush

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
From our robot last year:

Green if the bot detected the hopper was completely full with game pieces

Yellow during the last 30 seconds of the match

Everything else was just us expressing ourselves with our pieces of flair .

Basically, just put info there that’s critical to enter your driver’s brain. If it shouldn’t cause them to change behavior, don’t put it there.

link_counts.title: Office Space - Joanna - Your Flair - YouTube

posts.cooked: Green when in shooting range. Orange when 30 sec remaining. Team colors otherwise

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked:
Here’s a link to one of our offseason matches (we are 2539):

We used green to indicate that the robot was aimed, and the resting color was the alliance color. Our robot would flash white when it had two balls inside. We also had a machine learning ball pickup system, and the robot would turn purple when that was active.

We just started using a CANdle today, and we plan on using it this year for better control over our LEDs.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: So for our robot, we had several indicators from the LED strips on each side of the Limelight support brackets. Alliance color = normal operation Purple = targeting (when the operator selected for a target lock on the goal) Bright purple = target locked and ready to shoot Green = climb activated Here’s one of our matches from NCDCMP where you can see all the modes in action: https://youtu.be/caaIGItM0h4 We’re down front on red and run the five ball auto. You can see that the indicators work even during the auto run.

We kept ours pretty simple to conserve battery power.

Red - one Cargo Blue - two Cargo

The rest of the match they were off.

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: It looks like it works well, the only thing I might be concerned about is using red and blue when they are also the alliance color. Other than that it’s great!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
BrendanB:

Red - one Cargo Blue - two Cargo

Fish-based color analogies are the best.

posts.name: Luke Maxwell
posts.cooked:
shameless plug of our robot team 1757, our states were:

Green: two balls, turret on target Blue: one ball, turret on target Purple: two balls, turret NOT on target Yellow: one ball, turret NOT on target Red: no balls

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: 254 in 2017 is another good example. Flashed ring light on gear pickup.

suggested_topics.title: Bumper wood
suggested_topics.excerpt: This year, the backers don’t have a minimum thickness but I recommend that it should not go under 1/2 inch (~12.7 mm). We decided to use 3/4 inch (~19.05mm) plywood for backers.
